summary: After George Bailey (James Stewart) wishes he had never been born, an angel (Henry Travers) is sent to earth to make George's wish come true. George starts to realize how many lives he has changed and impacted, and how they would be different if he was never there.

reviews.content: My personal favorite Christmas movie and one of my overall favorites. Just a great movie- classic.

It's a wonderful life is a the best Christmas movie you can watch. A real great sitdown with your family and enjoy whilst you eat cookies and stuff your face with all kinds of foods. The movie balances family,love, anguish perfectly. The negative is the middle of the movie can be boring and drag on at times. Overall a great must see with the family during the holidays.

What a great movie to watch around the holidays, no matter whether you celebrate them or not, or even care for them or not to begin with, and that's probably what makes it watchable all-year-round. I don't think my input will add anything significant in describing how great this movie was and still is after so many decades, especially in terms of the message it compellingly conceives. After watching this, and no matter what you might be going through, you will realize that it is indeed a wonderful life.
It's a wonderful life is the perfect movie.

A timeless tale. Frank Capra's 1946 film about appreciating life, helping others and acknowledging goodness, no matter how hard life is or irrelevant one feels is sometimes more important than pursuing individual goals. It reminds us that we are not alone, that the lows in life should make us cherish the highs, and that we should recognize not only the impact we've had others, but what impact they've made on us. This is a film not only for Christmas, but for any time, one that helps us to see that, well, it really is a wonderful life.

George Bailey is the protagonist of the story. He's a very ambitious person, living in the small and boring town of Bedford Falls. He works in his father's building and loan firm and dreams of traveling around the world, but everytime something comes up and he is unable to leave Bedford Falls.  He and His whole family are in trouble because a lot of money has gone missing and George is blamed for it. When in reality the money was stolen by the evil Mr Potter, who is known as the richest and meanest man in town. On Christmas day he contemplated committing suicide because he thinks everyone would be better off without him. George's whole life is then shown through flashbacks to see just how he got to that place. He's desperate and doesn't see a way out and just as George is about to jump off a bridge, Clarence, his guardian angel, shows up and shows George what life would have looked like for everyone if he hadn't been born. 

The main theme of the movie is coping with failure and success in life, but there are also many components of love, family, friendship, and Christmas.
The main message of the movie is showing how one person can make a difference. Sometimes it is the lack of perspective that causes people to forget how much impact they have on others lives. Great evidence of this is a quote that comes at the end of the film when all is well again.George embraces his family under the Christmas tree and suddenly he finds a Mark Twain book with a message from Clarence that reads "No man is a failure who has friends". What this scene shows is how good relationships with friends and family are what truly means to have success in life.
Most of the movie is a little demoralizing and seems to go against the message of the movie and how everyone is more successful than they think, because through out the movie nothing seems to work out in Geroge's life. Everytime the opportunity presents itself he chooses to help other people instead of following his dreams even though he's punished for it. It isn't until close to the end when George realizes how much success he has had in his life as he looks at how many people he has helped. 

I saw this movie for the first time with some friends that wanted to watch a Christmas movie. And we saw "It's A Wonderful Life" , an old black and white movie. It was an emotional rollercoaster, never before in my life had a movie made me laugh, feel angry, and tear up so much.

This is my favorite movie of all time, I've probably seen it more times than anything else. Although it's a very old movie, it is a timeless masterpiece. George Bailey's story of trying to pursue his dreams and feeling like a failure because he hasn't  accomplished his goals is something that is very relatable and has spoken very personal to me has I have tried to make a difference in the world The moral of the story, which is how everyone can make a difference, is something that I believe can inspire any kind of person, so obviously I 100% recommend this movie.

George Bailey (James Stewart) is a pillar of his small community, always eager to offer a kind word or a helping hand to those less fortunate, willing to sacrifice his dreams to make the dreams of others come true.  However, when misfortune calls and he is faced with financial ruin and considerable legal problems, a guardian angel is sent to save him from his fate.  It is a touching and timeless story of redemption as one man comes to terms with the significant role he has played in the lives of others.  At the risk of committing some sort of cinematic sacrilege, it takes far too long for director Frank Capra to set up the story for the ultimate pay-off and there are a couple of scenes with some horrible jump cuts, but overall, warts and all, it is a rewarding viewing experience for the whole family.

It's a Wonderful Life is something truly special, and along with Scrooge, the original Miracle on 34th Street and Home Alones 1 and 2, it is something I watch every Christmas. Why? Because I love this movie, seriously I do. Looking through my 1000 or so reviews here, I couldn't believe I hadn't reviewed this movie; I have seen movies that I have loved and cherished since childhood and I have seen movies that belong at the bottom of the garbage. It's a Wonderful Life belongs to the former, although I am 17, I appreciate a good movie when I see one. This is more than a good movie, it's a timeless masterpiece, that holds up on repeated viewings and never loses its magic.

It's a Wonderful Life could have easily been overly-sentimental and clichéd, but the quality of the direction and the screenplay that others have summed up perfectly assured it was a beautiful, heart-warming and somewhat poignant film. While there are some funny parts, not bursting-your-gut funny but funny in a subtle sort of way, other parts are close to heart-rending. The direction from Frank Capra is excellent, sensitive and nuanced, and Capra shows even more talent as a screenwriter having penned one of the most honest and touching scripts ever in a film. Casablanca, All About Eve and The Shawshank Redemption all had wonderful scripts, but the script here has a lot to say about community spirit and shows that this film is much more than feel-good sentimentality. There is the element of feel good here, no doubt about it, but it doesn't overpower what the film intends.

Visually, It's a Wonderful Life is a wonder. I don't think it is dated at all, the cinematography is crisp, the black and white looks beautiful and the pristine Christmas scenery really does take me back. Some of my favourite ever memories was of Christmas, whether it was watching nostalgic Christmas videos, eating Christmas dinner or singing carols under the Christmas tree. Another thing I have to mention is that the movie is richly and beautifully scored, Dmitri Tiomkin's music here is absolutely gorgeous, lyrical, whimsical, nostalgic and most importantly it never felt intrusive in the more integral parts of the film. And I have to mention the story, never in my life(and I genuinely mean this) have I seen a movie where it communicates such a strong message and so well too. The story of a suicidal man who is shown the value of his life by his guardian angel is an effective, timeless one, imitated perhaps but never equalled.

Finally the acting is wonderful. James Stewart, and I seriously don't give a damn whether he was a racist or not and neither should you, is absolutely superb as George Bailey, a truly complex character who goes through such a lot to get to where he is at the end of the movie. George Bailey is like Mr Deeds, John Doe and Mr Smith rolled into one, and in my opinion only James Stewart could have given justice to a character that has self-doubt gnawed at his essential decency. Also the character change, like that of Alistair Sim's Scrooge at the end of Scrooge, was heart-breakingly believable. Donna Reed is radiant and charming as his wife, who is like a caring lover, devoted wife and dedicated mother, while Thomas Mitchell gives one of his more memorable performances as Uncle Billy. Henry Travers is a revelation as Clarence the guardian angel, but there is another performance I think is worth of mention. For a good morality tale, you need a good villain. Well in the name of Potter, you have one. Who better to portray him than the great Lionel Barrymore acting at the peak of his powers?

Overall, a timeless classic with a true and heart-rendingly poignant ending. 10/10, one of the easiest perfect scores I have made recently. Bethany Cox

This movie was a very heartwarming view of what matters in life and what makes it wonderful. It demonstrates the role of families in the 1940's which is one of traditional value. George's life shows different signs and symbols of the times and what the movie really shows about God and his presence and how he tries to help us. It gives emotional value with the relationship between George and Mary.

"It's A Wonderful Life" is one of Frank Capra's most touching and inspirational films and this masterpiece is the most inspirational of all time according to The American Film Institute.  The AFI also rated it #20 of the 100 Greatest Films of All Time (American films only). My family has an annual tradition of viewing the film, always in its original B&W version, around Christmas. The film deserves Its reputation and is truly a masterwork that is so realistically human and filled with every type of emotion we have as humans. What a wonderful and beautifully shot film that's looks gorgeous on blu-ray! Going from my parents vhs to dvd and now owning it myself in the definitive version on blu-ray, it holds a special place in my collection and heart! Gather family and friends and watch one of America's greatest and most inspirational films!

I used to think this was a heartwarming tale of family, faith and all that was good about America. Then a friend pointed out that it's essentially two hours of misery for two minutes of catharsis at the end. Still, what's better than having Frank Capra remind us that, while we might be stuck and thwarted in our dreams, it could be a helluva lot worse - so shut up, get back to work and let some angel get its dam wings.

Favorite Frank Capra Film, Favorite Jimmy Stewart Film. One Of My favorite Endings ever. Truly brings me to tears of Joy every time no matter how many times I watch it. The message is timeless as well. Very Unique story structure as 85% of the movie is devoted to the first act which I have never seen in another movie but it oddly works wonderfully and makes the ending carry that much more weight. Jimmy Stewart (My favorite actor of all time) is phenomenal and is character is one of Top 5 Favorite Heroes Of All Time for his relatability, selflessness and sincerity. Never does the film feel self righteous, cheesy, or overdramatic as a lot of films around this time do. It truly feels modern. Mr. Potter is one of My Favorite Villains of All Time for his heartlessness and greed, representing the worst of humanity in juxtaposition to George who represents the best. Even though this is watched mostly around Christmas this is so good you can watch anytime of the year and feel happy. The Final 5 Minutes will make anyone tear up with tears of Joy. One of the Best Endings I've Ever Seen.

One of the greats. Never fails to get me teary eyed, and that's hard to do for me. If I was to say a bad thing about it, it's that there's maybe a handful of lines that are awkward/clunky. Recommend watching in black & white the first time.

It's telling of the quality of this movie when the only things people can knock it for is something idiotic like being "too white" or "too christian". Look at almost every bad review on here and that's one of their reasons.

My favorite Christmas movie of all time. The film has a spectacular performance by Jimmy Stewart. A very heart warming story that will make feel the Christmas spirit. True the movie ends in Christmastime while the movie builds up the characters and story to its great climax.
A Christmas classic I'm head over heels in love with this glorious and triumphant movie.
they don't make movies like this anymore.. got heart

This film lost money upon release in 1946, but now is a holiday classic. It's a timeless film showing the value of life and friendship. George, a struggling man wants to kill himself after losing $8000, but eventually realizing that his existence has made a big impact on others. This is one of those classic films that will have appeal to almost every type of audience.
A Christmas classic for me for many years.  It is a wonderful story, with a joyful ending.
A classic, very memorable and good.
Excellent movie that never gets old. I've watched it every Christmas and will for the rest of my life.

A 76 year old pure cinematic masterpiece that continues to remind us of the greatness of life that we often take for granted. The content of character manifested in the admirable man, George Bailey throughout the movie and its sublimely ceremonious ending will never cease to inspire and move its audience. Not only does this movie absolutely entertain us with its impeccable storytelling and beguiling performances, it makes us better as human beings by the time the credits roll.  An epitome of why we watch and love movies.

A timeless classic that has entertained for decades and will continue to be one of the best Holiday movies ever made for generations to come. Watching the new colorized version of It's a Wonderful Life was a brilliant experience and a highly recommended one for fans of this masterpiece.

WARNING! THIS REVIEW HAS SPOILERS (It's a movie from 1946, I think almost everyone watched it)! Life is wonderful. It is worth a lot more than 8,000 dollars. George Bailey's personality irritated me a little bit, he's a guy who always puts money on the second plan, but it's impossible to be this way in a capitalist world, especially after the Great Depression or World War II. And Mr Potter (Lionel Barrymore), who's portrayed as the villain, is the actual voice reason of the film, alongside Mary (Donna Reed) and Clarence (Henry Travers). The film successfully doesn't contradict the messages "life's worth more than any money" and "'money doesn't buy happiness' is a lie". Despite looking antagonistic, they're, in fact, complementary. The movie is essentially George's journey back to reality, even though he was never out of it. I think a more appropriate expression would be "put his head in the right place". Oh, and the ending is undeniably heartwarming. And I got where "Sesame Street" picked up the names Bert and Ernie, hahaha!

What I don't understand is the rumor of how a standup guy like Stewart could blame is co-star actress for its initial failure.  Donna Reed was simply stunning.  She embodied, in fact, totally WAS, Mary Bailey.  Without her it might not have been nearly as wonderful.
It actually is a wonderful life.

This film, made just after the second world war, has an optimistic objective.  It begins with an attempted suicide and thereafter moves upward to a firework's ending.  It goes from deep depression to happiness thanks to the fantasy of Christianity, which begs the question why this guy warranted angelic intervention compared with others - especially considering the recency of WW2.  This is the least of its problems.   The film has not aged well.  The problem is it clearly has American audiences of the late 1940s in mind and one imagines the storyboard looking like a collection of Norman Rockwell paintings.  The combined effect is a fantasy belonging to a fantasy-view of American society - filled with Christian white people and the American can-do myth.  It's appalling.

No matter how often you see this perennial Christmas favorite, you will be entranced.  Flawless.  Indeed, it has become such a familiar part of the holiday landscape that those who have never seen it might dismiss it as "Capra-corn" sentimental and syrupy.  In fact, the movie's vision is that of a dark-edged world in which heroes are necessary.  George discovers his existence has saved his community from the cruelty of robber barons and more importantly, from its own greed and shortsightedness.

Made just after the war, it was a favorite for both leading man Jimmy Stewart and director Frank Capra.  It is easy to see why.  There's a delightful song and dance sequence, visually witty moments like the dance floor that converts into a swimming pool during a feverish Charleston competition, and a sophisticated dialogue.  Stewart gives the performance of a lifetime.  Alternately affable and bitter, he is the. movie's little man hero.   And if the movie is about broken dreams, it's conclusion is that these broken dreams can turn out to be a blessing.
Technically the best Christmas movie of all time, It's a Wonderful Life remains as iconic as its first release.🎄🎅

Frank Capra's (Here Comes the Groom, Arsenic and Old Lace) festive masterpiece still holds up with James Stewart (The Man Who Shot Liberty Valance, The FBI Story) magnetic performance and I'm shocked it didn't win next picture

As far as I’m concerned, this is the greatest film ever made. I have seen it 20 times in a movie theater and 40 times on DVD without commercials (which would be sacrilege). Sure, there are moments that now seem corny or schmaltzy, but in terms of emotional impact and transformational, even healing power, no other film comes close. This is actually quite a dark film, a film about suicide, and yet is funny, exhilarating, and deeply moving. My favorite filmmakers all agree.

Quite simply, my favourite movie of all time. ❤️❤️

The premise of the story is, of course, how a man named George Bailey keeps sacrificing his money and his desires all his life to help others in various ways over the years, and when later in life he is finally overwhelmed by his latest problems which he cannot solve himself and is ready to commit suicide, an angel from Heaven whose eyes are upon promotion is sent down to tell George about how all his self-sacrificing had saved so many people from disaster.

One can nitpick about various things in the movie: reading a Bible, there are references to cherubs and seraphs, angels whose status in Heaven is indicated by the number of wings they have; the fact that George, despite his frustrated ambitions, didn't do too badly-he has a nice wife and children and is not living in poverty, and not being eligible to serve in the military would not necessarily be considered by some people (including people who had) to be a bad thing.

My problem, though, is this-it turns out that Bailey has lots of friends because of all the good he had done, and they're willing to pay him back to get him out of his financial hole and save him from jail. Unfortunately, in real life self-sacrifice, especially excessive self- sacrifice, does not necessarily result in gratitude from those one had sacrificed for. They might necessarily take your actions for granted and in fact might regard you as a slave, which all too often happens in real life. Once your purpose is served, the sacrificer is discarded and forgotten, or even despised. And that, alas, would have been the far more credible ending.

Because of this, the movie was put in the public domain and television stations were able to air it for free. Stewart is excellent in the lead role, you really do see every single emotion that his character goes through. He is, by far, the standout performer, but there are of course good performances from the likes of Donna Reed (Mary), Lionel Barrymore (Henry) and Henry Travers (Clarence).

I did notice a few weird cuts in there, not that I hold that against it or did it affect my enjoyment - it's just noticeable. I see, via other reviewers, that there's a colour version - Channel 4 showed the black-and-white version over here in the UK. I can't say I felt the need for colour, which is always a good sign.

It's a Wonderful Life Review 
It's a Wonderful Life teaches us a lot about life with teaching us how to go about living our lives such as with improving our lives. It's very relatable with having characters that we can relate to particularly the character of George Bailey. James Stewart tops this off with an excellent performance. It does however have a fair amount of flaws.  
It's a Wonderful Life is about a down on his luck businessman who looks more at the negative aspects of his essence rather than the positive aspects of his essence. He looks at the negative aspects so much that he contemplates suicide however an Angel from heaven named Clarence saves him from doing so. 
George has plenty of financial problems with the town he lives in Bedford Falls and this comes from a bank owner by the name of Henry Potter who not only wants to do whatever it takes to own everything in Bedford Falls, but also wants to do whatever it takes to own all the money in Bedford Falls even if it means enabling people to live poor in slums. Mr. Potter reminds us of our selfish side or can relate to anyone who's just flat out selfish because he's willing to do whatever it takes to make himself satisfied, and it's said or believed that this is the only way to have fulfillment in life, but we don't have to always be selfish in order to have fulfillment in life we can be selfless, and this is what George Bailey represents. 
	George saves his brother Harry from drowning which leads to him giving him his money and this leads to him playing college football and shooting down many fighter planes and saving men from a transport during World War 2, which also leads to President Harry Truman awarding him the congressional medal of honor, and what this teaches us is that we can change the world for the better by being generous. George also gives out loans to good friends of his such as Violet and Tom and this instills us that we should be more generous than egocentric if we want a friendship to last for a long time or even forever. 
George does another devoted act by using Potter's money to turn a graveyard into a town with tons of houses called Bailey's Park, and what this proves is that we can improve our lives by being noble towards others because it makes us more likeable and because it can enable people to be noble to you by improving your life. An example would be at the end of the film when all of George's friends and family end up giving his wife and kids money, they had left over because of how generous he was to them by giving them money. 
George however looks at the negative aspects more than the positive aspects of his life with his financial problems and this leads to him forgetting all the good that he has done and pondering over suicide, and this leads up to his guardian angel Clarence showing him what the world would be like if he had never existed, which leads to the Bailey's Bros Building and Loan Association going out of business and his brother Harry dying at the age of 9 because he wasn't there to save him from drowning when he was a kid, and this leads up to him not becoming a war hero and receiving the congressional medal of honor. George's wife Mary has never married and perhaps this is because her one and only true soul mate was George, and what this teaches us that if we ever ponder or are about to commit suicide god forbid, we should think more about the positive rather than the negative elements of our lives and all the good we've done as opposed to all the bad that we've done or all the problems we've had.
	The character of Violet reminds sophisticated and popular people of themselves because she's not only nice looking, but she dresses nice as well, and in fact there are men who stare at her as she walks down the street, and this reminds me of when the character of Ilsa in the film Casablanca walks in the nightclub with her husband Victor and men stare at her and the character of Renault comments on her beauty as does George comments on Violet's beauty in It's a Wonderful Life.
	James Stewart really makes George Bailey come alive with his performance by adding lots of vigor, intensity, and strength to his voice especially in the scenes in which he has disputes with Henry Potter such as when he wants the people in Bedford Falls to live in decent homes rather than in slums, and when Mr. Potter offers him $20,000. He also adds a great quantity to his facial expressions exclusively during the scene in which Potter is talking to him in his office, and he squints his eyes as he looks at him as if he certainly despises him, and he looks down in shame when Potter tells him his weaknesses. There is also a scene worth mentioning when he gives George a very perplexed, shocked, and confused look on his face when he finds out his mother in other words his own flesh and blood doesn't recognize him in the world in which he doesn't exists, and during this scene there seems to be more emotions going on in his face than I can even describe.
	It's a Wonderful Life despite these strengths has a fair amount of weaknesses such as with plot holes with it never being explained as to why there's a bunch of animals in the Bailey's Bros Building and Loan Association such as a crow, squirrel, dog, and owl. It's a Wonderful Life is also disappointing with the case that none of the other performances in it are memorable, and the only memorable performance in it is that of James Stewart's performance his performance is so memorable that we wish the other performances in it were just as memorable or more memorable. I highly recommend It's a Wonderful Life despite having a fair amount of flaws and give it a score of a 9 out of 10.

If you haven't yet seen this movie...
Anyway, seeing it again this season and thinking about the difference it sets forth of those who worship wealth & money and those who choose instead love & honor.  The Potters of the world (ironic name that - what art thou but a maker of pots?) do not see human beings but only financial assets or burdens;
"to my father they were human beings - but to you, a warped, frustrated old man, they're cattle!"
The Potters do not show mercy when mercy is necessary, or compassion when it would be the right thing to do;
"have you put any real pressure on these people?"
"Mr. Potter, these people have children."
"well they're not my children!"
The Potters do not act in an honorable or even reasonable way;
"somehow I've misplaced $8,000 dollars"
"you've misplaced?" (he looks at his steward knowing it was Uncle Billy and not George who was at fault)
The Potters like to twist the knife once it's in, causing pain and agony towards others;
"Look at you. You used to be so cocky. You were going to go out and conquer the world. You once called me "a warped, frustrated, old man"! What are you but a warped, frustrated young man? A miserable little clerk crawling in here on your hands and knees and begging for help....I'll tell you what I'm going to do for you, George. Since the state examiner is still here, as a stockholder of the Building and Loan, I'm going to swear out a warrant for your arrest. Misappropriation of funds, manipulation, malfeasance..."
Those that pursue money, though, live in great fear too - fear of being found out, fear of not making the grade, fear of never having enough.  To measure all things by their financial worth is to be
"cooped up for the rest of your life in a shabby little office..." 
to deal with the "business of nickels and dimes and spending all your life trying to figure out how to save three cents on a length of pipe..."
The movie may seem a bit romantic, echoing that Beatles' line of "all you need is love" but it also seems to echo the older maxim from 1 Timothy that "the love of money is the root of all evil."  
George Bailey, a good man with noble dreams, consistently chooses the honorable path of self-sacrifice; but surrounded by a world that views money as the only defining factor (the scene of the '29 crash for instance) he eventually becomes resentful, fearful, and desperate teetering on the brink of real despair and losing the vision that, rich or poor, his little family loves him.  It takes a near-death event and the intervention of a silly little angel to cleanse the doors of his perception.  
"There must be an easier way to get my wings."
Thus this is the quintessential Christmas movie - not b/c of the singing of "Hark the Herald Angels" or b/c of the setting at Christmas time or the snow or the little town charm, but b/c the birth of the Christ child in our own hearts is a perennial event.  Bedford Falls is the world stage itself and the actors play out the drama of the human heart as it perpetually wrestles with despair.  "Behold," says the Lord, "I make all things new!"  And indeed, the birth of the Christ Child at this season symbolizes the cleansing of our own vision away from that enslaving view that the world is a shabby little town in which the only answer to life's questions is to acquire more money, more power, more worldly gain.  The Advent prayer from Revelation 
"the Spirit and the bride say, Come. And let him that heareth say, Come."
defies this dark vision and in a similar way George Bailey, having seen what the world without him looks like, returns in joy to his rollicking children, his drafty old barn of a house, and the love of his wife - only to find that no man is a failure who has friends.  Amen, come Lord Jesus.

It's a Wonderful Life has an unforgettable climax that sends a good lesson to audiences of all ages and has cemented itself in the minds of everybody who's seen either the movie or a video that spoofs the concept...and the rest of the movie that preceded it was pretty good too. Yeah, I was surprised that the iconic finale doesn't occur near the very end but fortunately there was such a well-done buildup to it that I didn't even complain. The acting is great, Frank Capra's direction is great, the cinematography is great, is there any reason why this isn't considered a Christmas classic, despite no Christmas decorations showing up until we're near the third act? You easily sympathize with George Bailey. The guy wishes to travel the world but he never does and it ends up taking his toll on him since he's trying so hard to make everybody else happy he feels like its come at the expense of his own happiness. The movie does show that those acts of selflessness mean that, if it weren't for somebody intervening, peoples' lives could've been much worse. I doubt my review will stand out amongst anybody else's, which is why I find it impossible to say anything anybody likely hasn't said already so I'll just tell you this: you haven't watched It's a Wonderful Life? Well, then, what are you waiting for? Next Christmas? Just remember that the iconic moment doesn't happen until near the very end and most of the movie is buildup towards it. But it is really good buildup.

Review: 
‘It's a Wonderful Life' is a Christmas fantasy-drama film directed by Frank Capra. It's based on the short story and booklet ‘The Greatest Gift' by Philip Van Doren Stern.
This movie is why I always say the ending to a movie is the most important part. I didn't classify this as a Christmas movie, nor was I 100% invested in the story until the final act of the film. I loved it!
The film stars James Stewart as George Bailey, a man who has given up his dreams to help others, and whose imminent suicide on Christmas Eve brings about the intervention of his guardian angel, Clarence Odbody (Henry Travers). Clarence shows George all the lives he has touched, and how different life in his community of Bedford Falls would be if he had never been born.
I honestly can't talk about the acting being good or bad, it was a different time back then and you really can't judge. I will say that I love James Stewart and I know what he can do and what he usually does. This was a different role for him to take on and he did a great job.
The story really doesn't pull you in, and it's not the most exciting. The movie does a good job at creating a protagonist that you are rooting for in the very beginning. You want George Bailey to succeed and travel around the world, but he always puts others before himself, until he feels he just can't do it anymore. The ending of this movie is brilliant and breathtaking. I found myself in tears by the end and it really captures that if you have friends you're never truly alone. I don't really consider this to be a true Christmas movie, being the ending is the only part where Christmas is even mentioned.
Overall, the movie is a heartwarming story that should be watched at least once in everyone's lifetime.
4/5
A true Christmas classic!

This was a major blind spot in my film knowledge as it is considered the most iconic Christmas film of all time, at least in the United States, and is frequently referred to in discussions I have had with other cineastes. One of my worries was that the film had been built up so much in my mind that it could not possibly match up to my expectations when I finally saw the film. I had enjoyed the films of Frank Capra in the past as It Happened One Night (1934) is one of the greatest romantic comedies ever made and the somewhat overlooked today You Can't Take It with You (1938) and in that way I did not like this film quite as much as I wanted to. It is a fine film considered on it's own merits but don't be too taken in by all of the hype as it may disappoint just slightly.

George Bailey, James Stewart, plans to leave the small town of Bedford Falls, New York to travel to other countries and then study but he is forced to stay after his father dies and he is forced to run the bank they own. He has met and fallen in love with former classmate Mary Hatch, Donna Reed, but his commitment to work and rivalry with the evil Mr. Potter, Lionel Barrymore, who drives up prices on property and intends to enslave the town leaves him feeling sad. When his brother, who was meant to take over from him, is married and offered a better job Bailey is resigned to the fact that he will spend the rest of his life in Bedford Falls. He is married to Hatch and has multiple children with her but struggles to keep the bank financially solvent and a blunder that his uncle makes leaves him broke and vulnerable to the possibility of criminal conviction. This leads him to consider committing suicide but the intervention of an angel causes him to appreciate what he has.

I suppose the wonder of the film is that it is able to take dark issues like suicide and financial struggles and tie them into a film that is made to appeal to a wide audience of children and adults. The moral struggle that Bailey faces is genuinely difficult and most adults can relate to giving up many of the dreams they had as youths to take care of their families or responsibilities passed down to them. The pain of seeing another, young version of yourself, in this case Bailey's brother, getting to achieve the dreams that you had is also a painful moment that rings true. What Capra does that is so fantastic, as he does in all of his films, is balance these darker elements with light comedic moments of slapstick or cheesy verbal gags. There is also the sweetness of the central relationship between Reed and Stewart which buoys the film and while at times Reed feels like too much of a good thing we are willing to forgive this because she is exceptionally good as the ideal woman. There is somehow not the overload of sentimentality that exists in some of Capra's lesser films as there is a brilliant balance to this film and even the most cynical are likely to be won over by it's charms.

Stewart makes a warm, likable lead and is totally convincing as the family man but he also gets a chance to do some serious dramatic work here as he is convincing as a hardened, embittered man for a brief stretch in the film. As previously stated Reed is excellent as the dream girl with her naiveté and total infatuation with Stewart in early scenes endearing us to her and her steady support only allowing our affection for her to grow. Barrymore is cast against type as he is the antithesis of Grandpa Martin Vanderhof and uses his persona as a cute, cuddly older man to shock the audiences and it is uncomfortable to find ourselves hating him. The only thing the film is missing is Jean Arthur but Capra does make sure to include Gloria Grahame playing to type as flirtatious floozy.

Most will find themselves loving this film and it is a decent choice if you are looking to occupy two hours of time but as much as there is that is good about it I was never really wowed and it felt far too long.

It's a Wonderful Life (1946) is director Frank Capra's masterpiece of humanistic drama. He revels into the simple pleasures of family, kindness, giving, and decency. While often played during the Christmas season, It's a Wonderful Life carries a timeless message of appreciating what you have in life. It remains a beautiful film and timepiece of how people can treat each other better just for the sake of doing the right thing.

Capra's direction is marvelous. The black and white colors are so crisp and carefully lit with bright lighting around the faces and moody street atmosphere. There are multiple long panning shots down streets and around corners that remain impressive technical feats. The few special effects of fading a person in or out are seamless, while the heavenly framing device is a charming as ever. Capra knew how to depict a man's entire life scene by scene by showing only what was necessary to understand how this man came to want to end it all. The graduation dance party over the pool is as impressive a sequence as the memorable Great Depression episode is likewise.

James Stewart is the protagonist George Bailey, whom we follow closely from adolescence to adulthood. Stewart is fascinating as the relatable everyman. You like him and want him to succeed because of his decency, but empathize with his pain as it all comes crumbling down around him time and again. Stewart gives one of his best and most versatile performances in It's a Wonderful Life. From joy for dreams to agony for loss, Stewart displays everything he had.

Donna Reed is similarly magnificent. She is as lovely and charming as any young leading actress, but so sincere in her love for George. You hope for her happiness and Reed demonstrates a playful, kind, loyal, and thoughtful wife as any man could hope to marry one day. Reed captures the magic of real love on film in It's a Wonderful Life.

I really appreciate the many great supporting roles from the boy that portrayed the childhood George to Lionel Barrymore as the greedy and lecherous Mr. Potter. Thomas Mitchell is so sweet and fun as Uncle Billy like Henry Travers is so naively innocent as George Bailey's guardian angel Clarence Oddbody.

Overall, It's a Wonderful Life is to be cherished as it is appreciated. It is a lively and entertaining film, but also particularly well crafted by the master Frank Capra. Give it a watch and see if you like it.

I seem to be one of only a small number of people who have seen this film, which for many has become a staple Christmas movie.
I watched a decent colorized version of a film that was originally released in black and white back in 1946.
The colorization technology on recent restoration of old films is very good and I couldn't tell I was watching an old black and white film.
I digress. Why has the film gained cult like status?
It stars James Stewart in the star role as a character George Bailey who has done good deeds throughout his life but now doubts his contribution to the world around him, making him contemplate suicide on Christmas Eve.
A trainee angel, Clarence literally saves him and in a parallel time line makes George realise what life would have been like without his interventions.
George part owns a loan company which faces financial problems and the possible imprisonment of George unless $8000 can be found to pay off the shortfall. 
George saves his brother's life for example in 1919. His brother as an adult is awarded the Congressional Medal of Honor for his bravery in the Second World War.
We see the actions of a greedy man Mr. Potter throughout the film. The opposite to George in helping the local towns population in owning their own homes. He comes across as an evil banker. Charging high rents for poor properties.
In the angel Clarence's parallel timeline the local town Bedford Hills is renamed Pottersville.
There is also a second story in the film. The angel Clarence is 'second class' and as yet has no wings. Saving George just may earn him his wings and elevate him to a 'normal' angel level.
In the end George's fate is saved as the townfolk raise the cash and Potter, who attempts to have George jailed sees his warrant ripped up.
A feel good film with some excellent performances. 
Stewart revelled in this kind of role throughout his film career.
The history of the film reveals copyright issues. Colorization issues as discussed and a top Christmas film that could really be watched at other times of the year.
